awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Manufacturing Feasibility of New Radiation Shielding Fabrics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to facilitate safety for medical radiation workers.  Many of these workers must wear radiation shielding as personal protective equipment for much of their workday. Currently used shielding garments are often unsterilizable, heavy and rigid, and difficult to inspect for cracks or tears; these issues add risk and cost to health care. The proposed radiation shielding materials will enable personnel to easily sterilize garments between uses, decreasing the risk of transmitting infections in operating rooms. Garments made from this material are expected to be more ergonomic to wear for long periods of time as well as easier to inspect and maintain. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will establish feasibility of a sterilizable and non-toxic radiation shielding fabric and will demonstrate radiation shielding efficacy and workability. Microparticle materials developed from a novel manufactured composite. This project will evaluate and screen potential polymers and processing conditions. The testing and evaluation plan will characterize materials in terms of strength, resistance to breakage, and chemical resistance. The project will assess radiation shielding efficacy using X-ray energies and conditions expected in a clinical setting. The fabric will also be evaluated for plasticity and its capability to be implemented in a garment that can be cleaned and sterilized.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Stark Street Materials Corp (SSMC) was founded to commercialize a bismuth particle technology developed at Portland State University and to bring to market bismuth particle-based radiation shielding materials and fabrics. Radiation shielding materials in medical facilities are often based on toxic lead-salt composites, and are heavy, difficult to store, un-ergonomic, and cannot be cleaned or inspected without considerable effort. The material SSMC is developing reduces all these issues, and is expected to be 10-20 % lighter than current radiation shielding materials. This technology is a fundament change to the current stitch and sew radiation shielding garment design, and the manufacturing feasibility of the material, and material performance was the primary focus of this project.

The outcomes of this project have included the demonstration of manufacturing and final material stability and elasticity studies. Silicone composites are known to be very stable, biocompatible, and excellent medical device materials, which make them ideal for this technology application. Importantly, silicones also have very good elasticity, which is important for ?fabrics? or molded sheets to worn as comfortable garments in a hospital setting. We screened a number of polymers during this project, and ultimately realized elasticity and flexibility were the most important factors for designing a high loading weight polymer composite to be used as a fabric. We the further adapted the bismuth particle chemistry for the silicone composites.

Bismuth is prone to surface oxidation and decompositions, particularly during the particle milling process. We screened a number of surface stabilizers to use in our ball milling production method, specifically for production of bismuth particles that will integrate well with silicones. We identified a candidate surface modifier that imparts good oxidative stability, and excellent incorporation characteristics and profile, and minimal environmental concerns or costs. We have identified raw silicones and identified integration and some molding techniques which enable us to produce composite sheets and fabrics of prototype materials that meet the outlined and identified target performances to compete in the current marketplace. We have additionally established a number of washing and processing steps for our materials that utilized inexpensive, renewable, and biocompatible reagents.

            The radiation shielding materials SSMC is building to bring to market have been shown to be an effective shielding material when tested using kilovoltage radiation and gamma radiation sources. We additionally have shown these materials retain good tensile strength, albeit a loss in elasticity, when exposed to a very large gamma radiation does. Materials show good stability under a variety of environmental and chemical conditions, including common cleaning solvents, heat, pressure, low temperature (liquid nitrogen) and autoclaving.

            During this project period SSMC worked with a medical device consultant and a medical device designer to generate a charter document and a prototype thyroid shield out of the radiation shielding material. The charter document outlines the path SSMC anticipates taking to produce these devices and enter the radiation shielding market. The prototype designs will be used to demonstrate to potential customers the final utility of the materials and fabrics, and how these devices are expected to outperform current radiation shielding materials and fabrics. SSMC has identified a commercialization and production partner who will partner with us to bring these garments to market.

 


Last Modified: 06/07/2022
Modified by: Anna Brown

Image
  • Bismuth ingot (A) is reduced to chemically stabilized bismuth micron particles (B), then compounded with silicone (C), and cured into sheets (D) or any shape needed to produce a high- density elastic and flexible radiation shielding device.
    Anna Brown
    Copyrighted
    Anna Brown
    Bismuth Ingot to Radiation Shielding
